docs.lead_paragraph: ''Always On Call: When Illness Turns Families into Caregivers,'' edited by Carol Levine (United Hospital Fund of New York, $20). If any toiler in the health care system deserves far more credit than he or she receives, it is the person who cares for an ailing loved one at home.

headline.main: When Friends and Family Fill Most of a Patient's Medical Needs

docs.lead_paragraph: Many new parents wonder if they know what they're doing. A new study suggests there may be grounds for these worries. A national survey by Zero to Three, a nonprofit clearinghouse for information about child development, has found what it calls serious gaps in many people's basic knowledge of raising children.

headline.main: Moms and Dads Flunk a Parenting Test

docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Sandy, age 56, could not do any of the floor exercises in her movement class because she was so overweight and out of shape that she had great difficulty getting down to the floor and up again. Even the class's 15-minute walk in the park tired her out before it was over, she recalls. But now, after working with an instructor who helped her improve her strength and agility, Sandy is participating in all the activities. She recently lost 25 pounds, though she says that at 150 pounds, she is still overweight. But she is far more fit than she used to be and is well on her way to becoming fitter, and leaner.

headline.main: Fat but Fit: A Myth About Obesity Is Slowly Being Debunked

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on gradual debunking of myth that to be fat is necessarily to be unfit; notes long-term studies of tens of thousands of people finds that not only is it possible for those who are overweight or obese to be physically fit, but when the obese become fit, their death rates are about same as lean people who are not fit; photo (Article in series The Fap Epidemic) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ballet is not usually considered a contact sport -- at least not when all goes well on stage -- but that doesn't necessarily make it safer than football. A new study has found that professional ballet dancers are injured just as often, and just as seriously, as athletes who play rough sports.

headline.main: Hidden Hazards of Tutus and Toe Shoes

docs.lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old dancer pushed her face into a pillow last spring as a needle probed one disk and then another in her lower back in a chilly radiology suite. Less than a teaspoon of dye oozed from the needle into the first disk, showing up on an X-ray as a dark puddle within the lighter disk. The needle slipped into the next spot, and again the dye pooled dark inside the disk. With the third injection, the dye flowed into the disk and started dribbling out through a tear. The patient cried out and clenched her fists as the seeping dye irritated the already angry nerve endings at the breach. So Dr. Gregory E. Lutz, a physiatrist at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, halted the test, called a diskogram, convinced that he had found the tear that had been causing the dancer lower-back pain for two years.

headline.main: For Back Pain Sufferers, a Technique Under Study May Offer Hope

docs.abstract: Intradiskal electrothermal therapy, or IDET, is a new therapy that may make it possible for some back pain sufferers to avoid serious spinal surgery; IDET is meant to alleviate back pain linked to some kinds of damage in disks between spine bones; photos; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve is a 17-year-old with a scraggly goatee, a propensity to wear Grateful Dead T-shirts and a strange medical complaint. A few months earlier, in response to symptoms of clinical depression, I had placed him on Prozac, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, known as S.S.R.I. Although he no longer complained of sadness, poor concentration and boredom, the problems that gave occasion to his being prescribed Prozac, he was now experiencing frequent disturbances of color and occasional moments when people he was looking at transformed into cartoonlike figures.

headline.main: Easy Answer May Not Be the Right One

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel comments on issues in treating adolescents who may be depressed as well as drug-abusers; comments on link between LSD and antidepressants; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of a broad new study, federal health officials have endorsed long-term use of corticosteroid inhalers for children with asthma. In a study published this month in The New England Journal of Medicine, researchers with the Childhood Asthma Management Program said the drugs were effective and safe. The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute financed the study.

headline.main: A Green Light for Children's Inhalers

docs.lead_paragraph: Bubonic plague, the Black Death that killed a third of the population in 14th-century Europe and millions more worldwide at the turn of the 20th century, is one of the most feared diseases. But when it comes to understanding how plague spreads, researchers in Britain say, it's not about humans, it's about rats. Scientists at Cambridge University have developed a new model for the dynamics of the disease, which is caused by a bacterium that usually travels to people from rats via flea bites. Among their findings are that plague can persist in a rat population for years without causing human cases, which helps explain a historical puzzle: why new epidemics kept cropping up in some European cities in the 15th and 16th centuries despite strict quarantine measures.

headline.main: Plague Can Wax When Rats Wane

docs.abstract: Scientists at Cambridge University develop a new, rat-based model for dynamics of bubonic plague, which is caused by a bacterium that usually travels to people from rats by means of flea bites; find that plague can persist in a rat population for years without causing human cases and that it is the characteristics of the rat population that determine whether the disease causes an epidemic among humans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from ''Always On Call'': Rabbi Gerald I. Wolpe Chairman of the advisory committee of the University of Pennsylvania's Center for Bioethics. On April 10, 1986, . . . my wife collapsed . . . from the rupture of two brain aneurysms. That began a phantasmagoria of events that has since determined the structure of our lives. In a traumatic second, she went from being an articulate public speaker, college administrator, teacher and extraordinary wife and mother to a severely damaged woman. In the past 14 years, she has defied almost every statistic. Very few people survive the level of cerebral damage she sustained. If . . . they do survive, the extent of brain damage . . . results in severe cognitive disruption. . . .

docs.lead_paragraph: Caffeine, and not some other unsuspected component of coffee, appears to be responsible for what some researchers have identified as coffee drinkers' decreased risk of developing Parkinson's disease, a new study reports. Researchers from the Department of Veterans Affairs found this year that people who drank moderate amounts of coffee appeared substantially less likely to develop Parkinson's, a debilitating neurological disease.
